project.name: spree-ember-auth
project.description: The default blueprint for ember-cli addons.

Authenticator.Spree.name: Authenticator.Spree
Authenticator.Spree.description:
The Spree Authenticator is responsible for Authenticating users against  your 
Spree store.  It assumes your server has the `spree_ams` gem installed.  The Spree
Auth initializer with dynamically create and set the Server Token Endpoint from
the Spree Core Adapter.

Authorizer.Spree.name: Authorizer.Spree
Authorizer.Spree.description:
The Authorizer is responsible for ensuring that each Authorized clientside request
contains the `X-Spree-Token` Header.  This loads the `@current_api_user` 
attribute in Spree, so that the User can successfully interact with the API.

Component.SpreeAuth.name: Component.SpreeAuth
Component.SpreeAuth.description:
A simple Fieldset that doubles as a Signin & Signup form.  Sends action:
`authenticateUser` or `createAndAuthenticateUser` depending on whether
`isSignup` is set to `true` or `false`.

**To Override:** You'll need to run the generator:

```bash
ember g spree-ember-auth-component
```

This will install a layout file at: `app/templates/components/spree-auth`, and
a component file at `app/components/spree-auth`, ready to be extended.

Mixin.UserRouteActions.name: Mixin.UserRouteActions
Mixin.UserRouteActions.description:
A mixin for providing utility methods to routes associated with User behaviour.
These are grouped together in the case the ambitious developers want to glob this
behaviour together into a single route, for a highly interactive experience.

**Important:** The `spree-ember-auth` install generator will attempt to overwrite your application
route.  If you opt out of this, or you're defining it in a pod instead, you'll
need to ensure that you're mixing Simple Auth's Application Route Mixin into your
application route.

```bash
import ApplicationRouteMixin from 'simple-auth/mixins/application-route-mixin';
```

This is essentially a thin wrapper on Ember Simple Auth.  If you'd like to
modify behaviour or catch events relating to Authentication, please refer to
the [Simple Auth Documentnation](http://ember-simple-auth.com/ember-simple-auth-api-docs.html)

classitems.description:
The endpoint where the Authenticator will attempt to Authenticate Users.  This
is set dynamically by the `spree-ember-auth` initializer, by building a URL
from the `spree-ember-core` adapter.
classitems.name: serverTokenEndpoint

classitems.description:
The Rails Resource that we're authenticating.  When using Spree's 
`spree-auth-devise`, this is simply `user`.
classitems.name: resourceName

classitems.description: The name of the unique key returned by the server on a successful authentication.
classitems.name: tokenAttributeName

classitems.description:
The name of the identification attribute of the user.  By default in Spree, 
this is email.
classitems.name: indentificationAttributeName

classitems.description: The token attribute name.  The Spree AMS Gem uses `token`.
classitems.name: tokenAttributeName

classitems.description:
Authorizes an XHR request by sending the `X-Spree-Token` header when the 
`session` is Authenticated.
classitems.name: authorize

params.name: jqXHR
params.description: The XHR request to authorize (see http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/#jqXHR)

classitems.description:
The action that is sent when `isSignup` is `false`.  This is caught by the action
defined in the `spree-auth-user-route-mixin`.
classitems.name: authAction

classitems.description:
The action that is sent when `isSignup` is `true`.  This is caught by the action
defined in the `spree-auth-user-route-mixin`.
classitems.name: createAction

classitems.description:
Triggered on the `spree` service whenever a user is successfully created 
through the `createAndAuthenticateUser` call.
classitems.name: didCreateUser

classitems.description:
Triggered on the `spree` service whenever the `createAndAuthenticateUser`
call fails to create a new user.
classitems.name: userCreateFailed

classitems.description:
Triggered on the `spree` service whenever the `updateCurrentUser`
call updates the current user successfully.
classitems.name: didUpdateCurrentUser

classitems.description:
Triggered on the `spree` service whenever the `updateCurrentUser`
call updates the current user successfully.
classitems.name: currentUserUpdateFailed

classitems.description:
The `authenticateUser` call simply wraps the `session#authenticate` method
provided by Ember Simple Auth.
classitems.name: extractAuthErrors

params.name: serverError
params.description: A JSON Payload containing server errors.

classitems.description:
The `authenticateUser` call simply wraps the `session#authenticate` method
provided by Ember Simple Auth.
classitems.name: authenticateUser

params.name: params
params.description:
A javascript object with identification, password, 
and password confirmation (optional).

return.description:
A promise that resolves successfully on a
successful authentication.

classitems.description:
The `createAndAuthenticateUser` method attempts to create a new Spree User,
and when successful, triggers the `authenticateUser` action.
classitems.name: createAndAuthenticateUser

params.name: params
params.description:
A javascript object with identification, password, 
and password confirmation (optional).

return.description:
A promise that resolves successfully on a
successful create then authenticate.

classitems.description:
The `updateCurrentUser` method attempts to save/update the current Spree user.
It expects that changes to the `session.currentUser` model have been made
in place, and doesn't take any arguments.
classitems.name: createAndAuthenticateUser

return.description:
A promise that resolves to the `currentUser`
when successful.
